a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:48): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: yeah, and border-radius, and margin-start, and padding-start, and user-select
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:48): well, those ones are in CSS3
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:48): although Webkit's syntax might not match the CSS3 syntax for border-radius
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:49): user-select might not be in any current CSS3 draft but it has been in the past
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:49): so has box-sizing I suppose
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:49): OK, well, I guess I can switch those back to e.g., _vendor_-box-orient
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:49): box-align/box-orient/box-margin are the most glaring annoyances because they've never been in any CSS spec
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:50): I don't think it makes sense to include non-standard properties at all, to be honest
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:50): most readers aren't going to know that those box properties are XUL related
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:50): webkit uses them also
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:51): yeah, because it implements parts of XUL layout
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:51): these rules are really UA-specific ways of achieving a certain rendering for the replaced element
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:51): so I'll just have the script drop the box- properties
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:52): IMHO we don't need or really want to display "typical UA properties" for replaced elements
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:52): yeah
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:52): they're implementation details
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:53): OK, but what about keeping the -start properties ?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:54): I could just have it change those to -left, but that would kind of misleading also

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:00): all your uses of 'appearance' are for replaced elements
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:00): like I said, I wouldn't include any "default display properties" for replaced elements
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (04:00): ok, so does the sys team have any intention of shifting specs to the other CVS server, or moving dev.w3.org onto the load balanced servers?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:01): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: I guess I'm not clear on on what a replaced element is. seems like 'input, input[type="password"], input[type="search"]' is not selecting a replaced element.. or is it?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:02): replaced elements are elements like form controls where (at least in principle) CSS does not define the rendering of the element
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:02): CSS treats replaced elements as black boxes basically
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:03): it just so happens that in Gecko and Webkit, at least, we implement replaced elements using CSS internally as well
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:03): but that is an implementation detail
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:04): I see. Is that true for "user-select" also?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:04): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: we can shift specs ourselves to www.w3.org and use ACLs to control access. but it's maintenance PITA, and no good reason to do it except for the dev.w3.org load issues
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:04): user-select is a CSS property, not an element
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:05): you're listing it on 'input' and 'textarea', which are both replaced elements
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:05): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: yeah, I know -- I mean the actual property
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:05): <audio> and <video> are also replaced elements
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:06): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: OK, I'll have it just drop what's there for audio

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:06): listing "typical UA stylesheet rules" for non-replaced elements makes some sense; authors can use that as a guide for how their stylesheets are likely to interact with typical UAs
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:07): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: right, that's what my main intent was for including it
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (04:07): for replaced elements, for which CSS does not define how author styles work, and in practice author styling only works in limited ways, it's less useful
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:07): yeah, I'm understanding that now
